issues.description: Whether § 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act applies to claims involving American Depository Shares (ADS) of a foreign company listed exclusively on a U.S. exchange.
issues.key_reasoning: The court held that § 10(b) applies because the ADS were listed and traded exclusively on a domestic exchange, falling squarely within Morrison’s first prong.

issues.description: Whether the plaintiff adequately pleaded actionable material misstatements or omissions in the proxy materials related to the freeze-out merger.
issues.key_reasoning: The court held that some statements (about projections, fairness, and summary of data) were actionable, while others (about game revenue grouping and MIIM revenue omission) were not.

issues.description: Whether the plaintiff adequately pleaded scienter for the alleged securities fraud.
issues.key_reasoning: The court found scienter adequately pleaded based on the motive and opportunity of conflicted directors to deflate the merger price for personal gain, and that their scienter could be imputed to the company.

issues.description: Whether the plaintiff adequately pleaded reliance, including the applicability of the fraud-on-the-market presumption.
issues.key_reasoning: The court held that the fraud-on-the-market presumption was available because the plaintiff relied on the market price in deciding not to exercise appraisal rights.

issues.description: Whether the plaintiff adequately pleaded loss causation for the alleged securities fraud.
issues.key_reasoning: The court disagreed with the district court and held that the plaintiff sufficiently pleaded loss causation by alleging he was induced to forfeit appraisal rights by the misstatements.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in dismissing the control person claims under § 20(a).
issues.key_reasoning: Because the court found a primary violation adequately pleaded, the control person claims should be reinstated.

issues.description: Whether the district court abused its discretion by denying leave to amend to add Altimeo Asset Management as a named plaintiff.
issues.key_reasoning: The court vacated and remanded because the district court denied leave to amend without explanation, which is disfavored.

key_precedents: Morrison v. National Australia Bank Ltd., 561 U.S. 247 (2010)
City of Pontiac Policemen’s & Firemen’s Retirement System v. UBS AG, 752 F.3d 173 (2d Cir. 2014)
Virginia Bankshares, Inc. v. Sandberg, 501 U.S. 1083 (1991)
Wilson v. Great American Indus., Inc., 979 F.2d 924 (2d Cir. 1992)
Tellabs, Inc. v. Makor Issues & Rights, Ltd., 551 U.S. 308 (2007)
summary_text: Plaintiff-Appellant David Monk challenges the district court’s dismissal of his § 10(b) securities fraud case for failure to state a claim. Monk alleges that materially misleading proxy materials issued by Shanda Games Limited (“Shanda”) as part of a freeze-out merger caused him to accept the merger price instead of exercising his appraisal rights. The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York (Carter, J.) dismissed Monk’s claims on the ground that he failed properly to allege loss causation. We hold that the district court erred in dismissing Monk’s claims. We agree with the district court that City of Pontiac Policemen’s and Firemen’s Retirement System v. UBS AG, 752 F.3d 173 (2d Cir. 2014), created a limited exception (for foreign securities purchased on foreign exchanges) to the general rule, set forth in Morrison v. National Australia Bank Ltd., 561 U.S. 247 (2010), that “transactions in securities listed on a domestic exchange” fall within the scope of § 10(b), as this case does. City of Pontiac, 752 F.3d at 179-181 (quoting Morrison, 561 U.S. at 267). We further conclude that Monk has adequately alleged material misstatements; that federal law governs the adverse interest exception to imputation for scienter in § 10(b) cases; and that the scienter of the conflicted directors—who had the motive and opportunity to deflate the merger price for their own financial gain—can be imputed to the company. We also agree with the district court that Monk may invoke the rebuttable presumption of fraud-on-the-market to satisfy transaction causation because he relied on the market price to decide not to exercise his appraisal rights. We disagree with the district court’s conclusion with respect to certain misrepresentations and on loss causation and hold that Monk adequately pleaded loss causation. We therefore AFFIRM in part and VACATE in part the judgment of the district court.
